channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: ISIS Has Executed Scores in Iraq This Month, U.N. Says
item.description: Reports include the slaying of soldiers, doctors, lawyers, women and children in a reign of terror throughout regions under Islamic State control.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Online Video Shows Japanese Hostages Threatened by ISIS
item.description: The video shows a militant with a knife threatening to kill two Japanese hostages unless the government in Tokyo pays a ransom of $200 million.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Islamic State group, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from a video posted online on Tuesday showing a man threatening to kill two Japanese hostages, identified as Kenji Goto Jogo and Haruna Yukawa.

item.title: Kenya Schoolchildren Tear-Gassing Under Investigation
item.description: Kenyan officials said they were looking into the conduct of police officers who tear-gassed elementary schoolchildren at a protest over a playground.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Among Snowden Leaks, Details of Chinese Cyberespionage
item.description: Edward J. Snowden, who was lauded for leaking N.S.A. materials, may have lost a little of his shine among Chinese leaders after his latest revelations gave details of Beijing’s own misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Edward J. Snowden was initially lauded by Chinese officials in the wake of his leaking sensitive United States documents.

item.title: Brawl Disrupts Drafting of Constitution in Nepal
item.description: Maoist opposition leaders threw chairs and microphones at members of the governing parties during negotiations, wounding about a dozen security guards.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Anti-government protesters marched in Katmandu on Tuesday.

item.title: A Cover-Up, of Sorts, for British Tabloid’s Page 3
item.description: By dressing a model in lingerie rather than showing her topless, The Sun, Britain’s best-selling newspaper, seems to have accepted a change in social mores.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, an Ingenious Scheme for Getting Out of Jail Early
item.description: Some prominent prisoners in China have received sentence reductions in part because of patents they received, but not necessarily for their own inventions.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Prisoners awaiting transfer to a newly built jail in Zhoukou, in the Chinese province of Henan.

item.title: Beijing Investigating Detention of 100 Chinese in Myanmar
item.description: A spokesman for Beijing’s embassy in Myanmar said the Chinese nationals had been detained on suspicion that they entered the country to engage in logging.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bill De Blasio Pays His Respects in Paris After Terror Attacks
item.description: After a meeting with Jewish leaders in the French capital, the New York mayor said that his city and Paris both “understand what it is to fight back” against terror.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER

item.title: 4 Thought to Be Linked to Paris Gunman Will Appear Before Judge
item.description: The four men, ages 22 to 28, are expected to be put under formal investigation in response to allegations that they provided logistical support for Amedy Coulibaly.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Vietnam Shows China Its Resolve With Military Posters
item.description: Military posters and billboards on display in Vietnam reflect the country’s notions of sovereignty regarding offshore islands that are also claimed by China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Gets a Raise, But Beijing Apartments Still Out of His Reach
item.description: Even after receiving a 62 percent raise on Tuesday, President Xi Jinping of China still makes less than the median United States wage. Fortunately for Mr. Xi, he does not have to live solely on his salary.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Recipient of Artificial Heart Goes Home
item.description: The news, reported by Carmat, the French company that developed the device, signals a milestone toward its possible commercialization.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Alain F. Carpentier, the French surgeon who invented the artificial heart, holding a valve that is part of the device.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Boko Haram Menace
item.description: The murderous Islamist insurgency has become a crisis Nigerian voters can't ignore.
item.dc:creator: By TOLU OGUNLESI
item.media:description: The scene of an attack by two female suicide bombers on a mobile phone market in Potiskum earlier this month.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Greece’s Accounting Problem
item.description: Standards like those used by leading governments, businesses, banks and investors would be a help.
item.dc:creator: By JACOB SOLL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A First Amendment for Australia
item.description: The Charlie Hebdo attacks have galvanized a movement for free speech on the other side of the world.
item.dc:creator: By GABRIEL SASSOON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Canada’s Flawed Sex Trade Law
item.description: The Conservative government’s reform efforts do more harm than good to the prostitutes they purport to protect.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE KAYE
item.media:credit: Mark Blinch/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press

item.title: North Korea Uses Defector’s Partial Retraction to Lash Out at Washington
item.description: Pyongyang said the United States should stop pressuring it over human rights, calling the defector’s reversal evidence that a U.N. report on its rights record was false.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Saturday Night in Taipei, and the Cool Kids Are at the Bookstore
item.description: At a time when many booksellers are struggling, Eslite is thriving, with 43 stores in Taiwan and one in Hong Kong. One secret to its success in Taiwan: It operates like a self-contained mall.
item.category: Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead (Book)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: Sean Marc Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Eslite Bookstore on Dunhua South Road in Taipei, which is open 24 hours a day. Eslite owes much of its success to being considerably more than just a bookstore.

item.title: E.U. Urges Cooperation to Combat Terrorism
item.description: European Union countries will assign security attachés at diplomatic missions overseas, and foreign ministers called for the establishment of a European system for exchanging passenger information.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: From left, Foreign Affairs Minister Laurent Fabius of France, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond of Britain and Federica Mogherini, the European Union’s foreign affairs chief, in Belgium.
